subject: Re: [junit] Re: Running tests multiple times w/ different config
msgSnippet: Craig, You have a point.  It looks like the parameterized runner could use a @BeforeParameter / @AfterParameter hook.  If that would be useful, could you open
messageBody:
Craig,

You have a point. It looks like the parameterized runner could use a
@BeforeParameter / @AfterParameter hook. If that would be useful,
could you open a Feature Request on SourceForge? Thanks,

David Saff

On 3/22/07, cwhite102 <craig.whitex@...> wrote:
>
> Thank you all for the suggestions. I'm just getting back on this
> now after being pulled to higher priority things. What could be
> higher priority than unit tests!?
>
> I've checked out the Parameterized test runner. Nice addition and I
> can make it work this way. However, one thing I'm not happy with is
> that it is the 'cross product' of the Test methods and parameters.
> Thus I can't have a bunch of test methods for a single parameterized
> instance. It's sortof missing the 'before'/'after' hooks needed to
> set it up the way I'd like - Configure, Test A, Test B,...,
> Shutdown. The 'BeforeClass'/'AfterClass' hooks don't work either as
> they are only called once in total.
>
> I sortof expected it to instantiate the class and then run all the
> test methods (seeing how it was on the constructor). But it doesn't
> work this way.
>
> Craig
>
>
>
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "hurne_jim" <hurne_jim@...> wrote:
> >
> >
> > JUnit 4 actually has a Parameterized custom test runner that allows
> > you to run the same test(s) with different parameters. Take a
> look at
> > org.junit.runners.Parameterized in the JUnit Javadoc.
> >
> > I've been working on an "XML" version of Parameterized that allows
> you
> > to store your test parameters in an XML file. It's part of the
> > JunitExt project (http://www.junitext.org). I must warn you that
> it's
> > still in the early stages of development.
> >
> > However, it sounds like using Parameterized might be easier than my
> > XMLParameterizedRunner, as you'll likely need to do something
> > programatically with Hibernate.
> >
> > The nice thing about custom test runners is that they work with
> IDEs.
> > For example, you can use Parameterized and still be able to run
> the
> > tests from within Eclipse.
> >
> > -Jim Hurne
> >
> > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Stephen Smith <steve@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Hi,
> > >
> > > Try using the Parameterized Test pattern - you should be able to
> find
> > > details of it online.
> > >
> > > Cheers,
> > >
> > > Steve.
> > >
> > > ---
> > > Stephen Smith, MEng (Wales).
> > > http://www.stephen-smith.co.uk/
> > >
> > > Gilles Scokart wrote:
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > You could write an abstract test with one subclass per
> database. The
> > > > parent class containing the real test, the subclass containing
> only
> > > > the setup.
> > > >
> > > > Or you can maybe try to do someting using test suite.
> > > >
> > > > Gilles
> > > >
> > > > 04 Mar 2007 23:36:58 -0800, cwhite102 <craig.whitex@
> > > > <mailto:craig.whitex%40rogers.com>>:
> > > > > I was wondering if anyone has a good suggestion to
> accomplish this
> > > > > goal.
> > > > >
> > > > > I'd like to have some of my automated integration tests to
> run
> > > > > multiple times, against various databases. This way I can
> make sure
> > > > > different databases (oracle, mssql, etc) don't exhibit
> different
> > > > > behaviour.
> > > > >
> > > > > Effectively, I'd like my unit tests to run multiple times
> with a
> > > > > little hook in between for me to setup my hibernate
> > configuration (to
> > > > > point it at each database).
> > > > >
> > > > > I'd prefer not to tweak anything in Ant because I'm using
> Netbeans
> > > > > generated ant scripts and, well quite frankly, changing them
> > scares me.
> > > > >
> > > > > I don't mind having a little code in my tests if needed,
> like
> > setting
> > > > > up a special suite or something.
> > > > >
> > > > > Any suggestions?
